entry.et: Middle English botme, from Old English botm; akin to Old High German bodam bottom, Latin fundus, Greek pythmēn

def.dt: :the underside of something

:a surface (as the seat of a chair) designed to support something resting on it used figuratively in phrases like the bottom dropped out to describe a sudden collapse or downturn lost millions when the bottom dropped out of the stock market
:the posterior end of the trunk :buttocks rump
:the surface on which a body of water lies
:the part of a ship's hull lying below the water
:boat ship
:the lowest part or place the bottom of the page
:the remotest or inmost point
:the lowest or last place in point of precedence started work at the bottom
:the part of a garment worn on the lower part of the body
:the pants of pajamas usually used in plural
:the last half of an inning of baseball
:the bass or baritone instruments of a band
:bottomland usually used in plural
:basis source trying to get to the bottom of these rumors
:capacity (as of a horse) to endure strain
:a foundation color applied to textile fibers before dyeing
:a fundamental quark that accounts for the existence and lifetime of upsilon particles and has an electric charge of −1/3 and a measured energy of approximately 5 GeV
:the flavor characterizing this particle
:really basically
:to furnish with a bottom
:to provide a foundation for
:to bring to the bottom
:to get to the bottom of
:to become based
:to reach the bottom
:to reach a point where a decline is halted or reversed usually used with out the team bottomed out in last place
:of, relating to, or situated at the bottom bottom rock
:frequenting the bottom bottom fish
:a fish that feeds at the bottom
:one that is of the lowest status or rank
:an opportunist who seeks quick profit usually at the expense of others or from their misfortune
:the practice of making purchases (as of stocks) when prices appear to be at their lowest point
:the essential or salient point :crux
:the primary or most important consideration
:the line at the bottom of a financial report that shows the net profit or loss
:financial considerations (as cost or profit or loss)
:the final result
:concerned only with cost or profits
:pragmatic realistic
:meat (as steak) from the outer part of a round of beef
:progressing upward from the lowest levels (as of a stratified organization or system) bottom–up management
:the lowest or most fundamental part or level
